If there are good men and good women who can uphold and recite the names of the thousand buddhas of the Worthy Eon,
they will surely see Maitreya, and also see Ruci, and will be free from all difficulties.

I take refuge in such immeasurable and boundless great bodhisattva mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
I respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.

Homage to the auspicious pratyekabuddhas, homage to the pratyekabuddha CÄ«rÄ, homage to the pratyekabuddha CÄ«rá¹‡a, homage to the pratyekabuddha Upa-cÄ«rá¹‡a, homage to the pratyekabuddha á¹šá¹£abha, homage to the pratyekabuddha Puá¹£ya-Å›uddha, homage to the pratyekabuddha Su-gandha-dhara, homage to the pratyekabuddha AÅ›oka, homage to the pratyekabuddha Upa-Å›oka, homage to the pratyekabuddha PÅ«rá¹‡a. I take refuge in these and other innumerable pratyekabuddhas.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I next repent.
Disciples!
Having already repented of the three karmas of the body and the four offenses of speech,
I next repent of all hindrances in relation to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.

Therefore, the sÅ«tras say that a human body is difficult to obtain, the Buddha's teachings are difficult to hear, the Sangha is difficult to encounter, it is difficult for faith to arise, the six sense faculties are difficult to possess, it is difficult to find a good friend, and it is difficult to give rise to fear.

But now, having together planted wholesome roots, we have obtained this human body with the six sense faculties complete, and again encountering good friends, we have heard the true Dharma. Yet within this, we each have not been able to wholeheartedly apply ourselves with diligence, fearing that in the future we will long be submerged in myriad sufferings without any hope of escape.
Therefore, today we must be sincere, ashamed and remorseful, and bow our heads to take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha Full Moon Light in the East, Homage to the Buddha Sovereign King in the South, Homage to the Buddha Boundless Light in the West, Homage to the Buddha Diamond King in the North, Homage to the Buddha Lion's Roar in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha Fragrant Elephant's Play in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha Sumeru Appearance in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha Jewel Supreme Virtue in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha Jewel Blue Lotus Flower in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha Vast Virtues in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, always covered by ignorance, with heavy afflictions obstructing the mind, seeing Buddha's images but unable to respectfully venerate them, being disrespectful to the Saá¹…gha and cruelly harming good friends, destroying stÅ«pas and temples, burning Buddha images, drawing blood from the Buddha's body, or placing the venerable images in lowly places in one's own flower hall, causing them to be smoked by incense, exposed to the sun and rain, blown by the wind, covered in dust and filth, and damaged by sparrows and rats, living and sleeping with them without ever paying respect, or leaving the images naked and never adorning them, or covering them with lamps and candles, opening and closing the halls, obstructing the Buddha's light.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless, and today I sincerely confess and repent.
Furthermore, disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we may have held scriptures with unclean hands in the Dharma hall, or placed scriptures on beds, disrespecting them when sitting or rising, or stored them in boxes with insects, causing them to rot and decay, or with pages falling out of order, or with pages missing or torn, or with ink smudged, and we have neither repaired them ourselves nor entrusted others to do so.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless, and we now confess them, taking refuge and repenting.

We may have slept on the ground listening to the sutras, or read and recited while lying on our backs, or spoken loudly and laughed, disturbing others listening to the Dharma, or misinterpreted the Buddha's words and explained the meaning of listening in a biased way, speaking of non-dharma as dharma and of dharma as non-dharma, speaking of non-offenses as offenses and of offenses as non-offenses, speaking of light offenses as heavy and of heavy offenses as light.

Or copying the beginning and placing it at the end, copying the end and placing it at the beginning, placing the beginning and end in the middle, and the middle in the beginning and end, adorning the text with ornate phrases and placing it in one's own canon, or for the sake of offerings, fame, and respect, teaching the Dharma to others, lacking the mind of virtue and seeking the faults of Dharma teachers, and engaging in debate and criticism without reason.
Not seeking to understand and attain supramundane teachings, or slighting the Buddha's words and respecting heretical teachings, slandering the Mahayana and praising the ÅšrÄvaka path.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless, and today we sincerely confess and repent.
Furthermore, disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we have created obstacles within the Saá¹…gha, killing arhats, disrupting the harmony of the Saá¹…gha, harming those who have given rise to the mind set on supreme enlightenment, cutting off the Buddha's lineage and preventing the Dharma from being practiced.

Or, having abandoned the human path, they whip and torture monks, cruelly beating and driving them, adding bitter words of slander, or breaking precepts, breaking discipline, and breaking dignified deportment, or encouraging others to abandon pure conduct and engage in the five desires, or pretending to have the proper appearance, spying and stealing as a thief.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless. Today, with a sense of shame and a sincere mind, we repent and confess.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we have either been naked or dressed in single garments in front of scriptures and images, with dirty feet stepping on the Buddha's hall and pagoda, or wearing shoes and entering the monastery, spitting in the halls and rooms, defiling the Buddha's and Sangha's ground, or sharing the same bed with monks, defiling their Dharma robes, riding in carriages and driving horses, pushing and colliding with the monastery buildings.

Such offenses committed in the midst of the Three Jewels are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, we take refuge and repent before the Buddhas, the Venerable Dharma, and the Holy Sangha in the ten directions.

May disciples, by repenting of all the offenses and hindrances created between the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and by the merit generated, wish to always encounter the Three Jewels in life after life, to revere and respect them without satiation, with heavenly silks, wonderful brocades, jeweled garlands and canopies, and hundreds of thousands of musical instruments and rare flowers and incense, which are not of this world, to always make offerings.

If not yet enlightened, first go to request the opening of the nectar gate, if entering nirvana, may I always be able to make the final offering, in the Sangha cultivate the six harmonies and respect, attain the power of freedom, promote the Three Jewels, above propagate the Buddha's Way, below transform sentient beings.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Mahayana Lotus Treasure-Reaching Monk on Retribution, Treasure-Reaching Previously Entered the Burning Feet Hell.
Why is it called the Burning Feet Hell?

The hell was seventy yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls and iron nets covering the sky above, with fierce flames burning the sinners. There were also iron spears as sharp as swords stabbing the sinners, with the ground on fire leaving no space in between.
In the west gate were eight thousand monks, crying out:
What sins have we committed to come into this place?
The horse-headed rakshasa grabbed an iron hammer, pushed the sinners forward with the tip, and kicked them with his feet, stabbing them with iron spears step by step.

In one day and night, they suffered myriad punishments, dying a thousand times and being reborn a thousand times, dying ten thousand times and being reborn ten thousand times. After leaving hell, they were born among humans with incomplete bodies.
Baota heard this and wept, saying:
What karmic deeds did these people commit to come into this place?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied:
These Å›ramaá¹‡as receive the pure precepts of the Buddha but do not uphold them purely. Their feet are impure, and they walk on the Buddha's ground and the monks' ground;
Or they ride donkeys and horses and go in and out of the gates in front of the Buddha's images, without a sense of shame. Because of these offenses, they fall into this hell.
